#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Finnish phrasebook
#Text=Finnish
#Text=( suomen kieli , suomi ) is spoken in Finland and by Finns elsewhere , predominantly in Scandinavia .
#Text=Whether travellers to Finland need to learn Finnish is doubtful , since most Finns — including virtually all under 50 — speak at least some English .
#Text=However , since so few people make the effort , you 're guaranteed to get delighted reactions if you try .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Finnish is a Finno-Ugric language and hence completely unrelated to most other languages .
#Text=In particular , Finnish has grammatically nothing at all in common with the Nordic languages , English or Russian .
#Text=Although there are many old loan words especially from Swedish but also from other European languages , they are not necessarily recognizable due to the very different phonology .

#Text=The use of modern neologisms instead of borrowing is common , but there may be a less used loan word in addition to the neologism : a polygon may be called polygoni , although the common word is monikulmio ( a direct translation from the Greek ) .
#Text=The origin of Finnish and its relatives traces back over 5000 years to nomadic peoples of the Ural mountains in Russia that migrated westward .
#Text=The details of the migration and the relations between languages are still topics of scientific debate .
#Text=The closest major modern relative , Estonian , is spoken across the Gulf of Finland .
#Text=The Sámi languages of Lapland and the Murmansk Peninsula are also related , as are a host of small languages in Russia .

#Text=While Hungarian is not by any means close , Hungary and Finland have a special relationship as Finnish for a long time was the only other Finno-Ugric language that was a main language of a sovereign country .

#Text=Except for Kven in Northern Norway , Meänkieli in northern Sweden , Karelian , spoken by a minority across the eastern border , some other minority languages in Russia , and arguably Estonian , Finnish is not close to mutual intelligibility with any of its relatives .
#Text=Finnish is an agglunative language , and suffixes express what English expresses mostly with prepositions .
#Text=For instance , junalippu Helsinki in means " train ticket to Helsinki " , while junalippu Helsinki is hard ( but possible ) to understand .

#Text=Also new words are often formed from the same root by endings : kirjain , kirjasin , kirjuri , kirjoitin , kirje , kirjelmä , kirjasto and kirjaamo are all substantives related to kirja , " book " ( letter , font , bookkeeper , printer , ... ) , and then there are related verbs and adjectives .
#Text=Reading signboards can be difficult as use of loan words is uncommon , and those used are not necessarily recognized .
#Text=Using a dictionary , especially for longer texts , is complicated by the word inflection ; also the stem of many words varies somewhat ( such as lippu , lipun for ticket ) .
#Text=Colloquial speech differs significantly from what is described here : ( minä ) olen → mä oon ( " I am " ) .
#Text=The formal pronunciation is still more or less what you will hear in the news , what is taught in school and what is easiest for others to understand .
#Text=Pronunciation
#Text=The Finnish language is fairly easy to pronounce : it has one of the most phonetic writing systems in the world , with only a small number of simple consonants and relatively few vowel sounds .
#Text=Native English speakers tend to have the most problems with vowel length and the distinction between the front vowels ( ä , ö , y ) and back vowels ( a , o , u ) .

#Text=English does make similar distinctions – consider the " a " sounds of father ( back ) and cat ( front ) , or the difference in the " i " sound for bit ( short ) and beat ( long ) – but you will need to pay extra attention to it in Finnish .
#Text=In Finnish , all vowels are single sounds ( or " pure " vowels ) .
#Text=Doubled letters are simply pronounced longer , but it 's important to differentiate between short and long sounds .
#Text=Example :
#Text=The basic Finnish alphabet consists of the following letters :
#Text=Additionally the letters š and ž appear in a small number of loanwords and are pronounced like English sh and as s in trea s ure , respectively .
#Text=The letter w also occurs infrequently in proper names and is treated identically to v .
#Text=Lastly , the letter å occurs in some Swedish proper names and is pronounced like a Finnish " oo " ( similar to English " aw " as in " law " ) .
#Text=The beginning learner needs not worry about these minutiae .
#Text=Vowels
#Text=Long vowels are indicated simply by doubling the vowel in question .
#Text=a : like a in f a ther , but short and clipped
#Text=aa : like a in f a ther
#Text=e : like e in g e t
#Text=ee : not found in English , but just stretch out the e sound
#Text=i : like i in b i t
#Text=ii : like ee in b ee t
#Text=o : like o in n o r
#Text=oo : stretch out the o sound
#Text=u : like u in r u le — that 's the same u as in German , Italian or Spanish
#Text=uu : stretch out the u sound
#Text=y : like German ü , similar to ew in f ew but with lips rounded ( transcribed uu )
#Text=yy : not found in English , but just stretch out the y sound
#Text=ä : like a in c a t
#Text=ää : like a in b a d
#Text=ö : like German ö , similar to e in h e r ( transcribed eu )
#Text=öö : not found in English , but just stretch out the " ö " sound
#Text=Diphthongs ( vowel sequences ) like the uo of Suomi ( Finland ) are common .
#Text=They retain the individual sounds of their vowels , but are slightly blended together to be pronounced in one " beat " .
#Text=Consonants
#Text=If a Finnish consonant is doubled , it should be pronounced lengthened .
#Text=For plosives like p , t , k , this means getting your mouth ready to say it , but pausing for a moment .
#Text=Hence mato ( worm ) is " MA-to " , but matto ( carpet ) is " MAT-to " .
#Text=b : as in English or approximated as p ( rarely if ever used in native Finnish words )
#Text=c : only in loanwords , pronunciation approximated as s or k
#Text=d : as in English or as t ( in native words only in conjugated words , with big variations between dialects )
#Text=f : as in English or approximated as v ( rarely if ever used in native Finnish words )
#Text=g : like g in g et or approximated as k ( rarely if ever used in native Finnish words , except in ng , see below )
#Text=h : like h in h otel , pronounced more strongly before a consonant
#Text=j : like y in y es
#Text=k : similar to English k , but unaspirated and slightly voiced
#Text=ks : like English x
#Text=l m n : as in English
#Text=ng : like ng in si ng
#Text=nk : as ng + k
#Text=p : similar to English p , but unaspirated and slightly voiced
#Text=r : trilled , as in Spanish pe rr o
#Text=s : like ss in hi ss
#Text=t : as in English
#Text=v w : like v in v ine
#Text=z : like ts in ca ts ( not used in native Finnish words )
